awd_titl_txt: Neurocognition of speech comprehension in social context: speaker identity and listener experience
awd_abstract_narration:
The Directorate of Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences offers postdoctoral research fellowships to provide opportunities for recent doctoral graduates to obtain additional training, to gain research experience under the sponsorship of established scientists, and to broaden their scientific horizons beyond their undergraduate and graduate training. Postdoctoral fellowships are further designed to assist new scientists to direct their research efforts across traditional disciplinary lines and to avail themselves of unique research resources, sites, and facilities, including at foreign locations. This postdoctoral fellowship award supports a rising scholar at the intersection of Linguistics and Neuroscience. Worldwide, there are more multilingual than monolingual speakers and, by extension, more accented than non-accented speakers of English and many other world languages (e.g., Spanish, Mandarin, Arabic). Social psychology and sociolinguistic research suggests that foreign accent often leads to stigmatization and negative social biases. The majority of the world's speakers probably experience some type of stigmatization or stereotyping based on their non-standard accent. To improve intercultural interactions and global communication, better insights into how foreign accent affects comprehension, decision-making, and evaluation are needed. This research project addresses an important yet under-studied area of research in the neurocognition of language: the effects of speaker identity as a pragmatic social cue that influences language comprehension, and the impact of listener experience and attitudes on comprehension. Specifically, the project tests how foreign-accented speech impacts spoken language comprehension in four groups of listeners who differ in their prior experience with foreign-accented speakers: monolingual adult listeners, monolingual child listeners, and two groups of bilingual listeners (bilinguals with the same or a different foreign accent as the speaker). The interdisciplinary research project adds insight into the factors that underlie relationship-building among speakers and listeners from different language backgrounds, which is particularly important given that listeners tend to use language attitudes and cues, such as accent, to stereotype speakers' attributes and make decisions about them. This project informs cross-cultural communication, especially for education, business, law, judicial sectors, and health and welfare sectors, where professionals and clientele frequently interact with people from different language backgrounds who speak with non-standard accents. Ultimately, the outcomes of the research will contribute to decreasing the potentiation of social disparity and reducing the entrenchment of negative social biases. Because the project takes a socio-contextual approach in the brain-based study of language, it also contributes to bridging neuroscience research with applied fields, including education.

This research project is the first neurocognitive study on how foreign-accented speech impacts language comprehension in four groups of listeners who differ in their experience with foreign-accented speakers. The multi-disciplinary approach combines insights and methods from cognitive neuroscience, sociolinguistics, and developmental psychology to investigate the interplay of language attitudes, accented speech comprehension, and neural signatures of language processing. The research design uses Event-Related Potentials (ERPs) and analyses of neural oscillations to study the neural correlates of how listeners' experience with foreign-accented speech and language attitudes affect language comprehension. The project tests both child and adult listeners and yields important insights into the development of neuropragmatic sensitivity in language comprehension and introduces linguistic pragmatics into neuroscience research. Additionally, including two groups of bilingual listeners identifies neuropragmatic effects on spoken language comprehension in non-native listeners. This is crucial considering that the majority of the world's speakers are bi- or multilingual, making non-native listening a global social norm. Due to its interdisciplinary motivation and design, the project establishes the groundwork for future research on interactions among social, individual, and neurobiological factors in language and communication.

por.por_cntn:
In our 21st century society, speakers and listeners from different language backgrounds interact frequently and the global prevalence of multilingualism entails that these interactions often involve at least one non-native language speaker. One of the most discernible features of a non-native speaker is a foreign accent and for many listeners, foreign accents are difficult to understand, particularly if one is not familiar with the accent in question. This difficulty produces consequences not only for the conversation at hand, but for foreign-accented speakers in other notable ways. For example, foreign-accented speakers may experience increased negative stereotyping, reduced credibility among non-foreign-accented peers, lower employment opportunities, and lower school evaluations. Given these social consequences, it is important to understand the processes that underlie foreign-accented language comprehension in different types of listeners. This increased understanding can inform ways to affect those processes and help reduce disparities between how listeners respond to foreign-accented speakers and how they respond to native-accented speakers.

Towards this aim, the project examined the brain's processing of foreign-accented and native-accented language in different groups of listeners. These listeners differed in the type of experience they had with the target foreign-accented speaker identity in the project (Chinese-English foreign-accented speaker identity): adult monolingual English listeners, child monolingual English listeners, and adult bilingual listeners who shared non-native speaker identity with the speaker but differed in whether they also shared the specific foreign-accented identity with the speaker (Chinese-English bilinguals, Spanish-English bilinguals). We examined two domains of language, semantic (meaning) processing and grammar (structural) processing in each of these groups to additionally determine whether foreign-accented speaker identity affects language domains differently.

The findings of the project show that when measuring comprehension by asking people to respond to sentence comprehension questions, both foreign-accented and native-accented speech are understood very well by all groups of listeners. This suggests that even though listeners think they have difficulty understanding foreign-accented speakers, their comprehension is actually very similar for both foreign- and native-accented speakers.

Fine-grained measures of brain activity provided additional details. The results for semantic processing show that, across all of the listener groups, the brain response to native-accented speech indicated fluent, efficient semantic processing whereas the brain response to foreign-accented speech indicated slightly slower semantic processing. The results for grammar processing produced a more complex picture across the different listener groups. For adult monolinguals, the brain response to foreign-accented grammar information was either absent or suggested more semantic than structural processing of the grammar information, depending on whether listeners were able to identify the foreign-accented speaker identity. Child monolinguals were sensitive to native-accented grammar information, but did not show any brain response to the same information produced by the foreign-accented speaker. Regarding the adult bilinguals, both the Spanish-English bilinguals and Chinese-English bilinguals (who share the foreign-accented identity with the speaker) were similarly sensitive to grammar.

The project's outcomes demonstrate that comprehension of both foreign-accented and native-accented speakers is very high among all listener groups examined, though more fine-grained analyses of brain activity reveal subtle differences for semantic and grammar processing of foreign- and native-accented speech. Regardless of listener experience, semantic processing is more difficult when listening to foreign-accented speech. Grammar processing, on the other hand, appears to be more sensitive to different types of listener experience regarding the brain's language processing.

Because of the project's multifaceted design, it has provided extensive training for researchers at all levels who were involved: postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate. The project has also contributed to science education initiatives and public outreach activities through demonstrations of how brain science works to K-12 students and their families, including demonstrations of brain activity recordings. Additionally, the brain-based differences evidenced in the project are being further explored in related research that has stemmed from this work; thus, the project is not only advancing scientific knowledge but generating new research. Ultimately, the project's outcomes will help inform the ways in which differences in the processing of meaning and structure contribute to foreign-accented language comprehension difficulties and the associated social effects of foreign-accented speaker identity.
